title: 109_hr3492
content: The "Consumer Credit Card Protection Act of 2005" prohibits universal defaults on credit card accounts. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits creditors from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits credit card issuers from increasing interest rates on consumer accounts for reasons unrelated to consumer actions, and requires clear disclosure to consumers. SEC. 3. BOX DISCLOSURE OF PAYMENT PERIOD FOR MINIMUM PAYMENTS ON CREDIT CARD BALANCE. Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances. This includes clear and conspicuous repayment information in a tabular format, showing the required minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and a percentage of the outstanding balance. The amendment to Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act introduces new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances. This includes providing clear repayment information in a tabular format, showing the required minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and a percentage of the outstanding balance, along with the estimated number of months to pay off the balance by making only the minimum payments. The amendment to Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act requires consumers to pay the minimum monthly payments and prohibits further credit advances on the account. Applicable terms include the APR for disclosures. The creditor must apply the applicable annual percentage rate of interest in effect on the disclosure date, considering different rates for various outstanding balance portions. The creditor must consider different rates for various outstanding balance portions when disclosing the annual percentage rate of interest, including temporary or introductory rates that may change. The creditor must consider different rates for various outstanding balance portions when disclosing the annual percentage rate of interest, including temporary or introductory rates that may change based on an index or formula for subsequent interest rate adjustment. When disclosing the annual percentage rate of interest, the creditor must consider the current rate and a rate based on an index or formula for future adjustments. The creditor must disclose the annual percentage rate of interest based on an index, formula, or contractual provision that would be in effect as of the disclosure date for the remainder of the amortization period. SEC. 4. ADVANCED NOTICE REQUIRED BEFORE INCREASING RATES OR FEES ON CREDIT CARD ACCOUNTS. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts. The Truth in Lending Act now requires advance notice of any interest rate increase on credit card accounts, ensuring that changes take effect no less than 30 days after the obligor receives a specific notice. The Truth in Lending Act mandates advance notice of any interest rate increase on credit card accounts, with changes taking effect no less than 30 days after the obligor receives a specific notice. Changes in annual percentage rates due to a change in another indexed rate must be implemented immediately, while other rate changes require a 60-day notice. The Truth in Lending Act requires advance notice of any interest rate increase on credit card accounts, with changes taking effect no less than 30 days after receiving the notice. Changes in annual percentage rates due to an indexed rate change must be implemented immediately, while other rate changes require a 60-day notice. No fees, including annual fees, late payment fees, or over-the-limit fees, can be imposed on credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan. The Truth in Lending Act mandates advance notice of any interest rate increase on credit card accounts, with changes effective no less than 30 days after receiving the notice. For credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan, no fees, including annual fees, late payment fees, or over-the-limit fees, can be imposed before the end of a 30-day period following the receipt of a specific notice of fee imposition. The notice requirements for fee imposition under the Truth in Lending Act mandate separate mailing or emailing of notices to consumers without any advertising. The notice must explain how, when, and why a fee will be imposed and provide options for the consumer to address it. The notice pursuant to paragraph (2) must include an explanation of how, when, and why a fee will be imposed, along with options for addressing it.
